desc: The MYOD gene encodes a member of the bHLH family of transcription factors. MYOD, together with the closely related MYF5, MRF4 and MYOGENIN regulatory transcription factors, control myogenic differentiation. MYOD commits mesoderm cells to a skeletal myoblast lineage and regulates their continued state and it can also regulate muscle repair (PMID:16099183). MYOD removes cells from from the cell cycle by increasing the transcription of p21 and myogenin and this is important to switch cellular proliferation to differentiation. Loss of this control would lead to the formation of rhabdomysarcoma (PMID:16099183, PMID 12783965). MYOD is rarely mutated in embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (PMID:25295632, 24824843, 24793135, 24272621)

articles.title: Transactivating mutation of the MYOD1 gene is a frequent event in adult spindle cell rhabdomyosarcoma.
articles.reference: Szuhai K et al. The Journal of pathology. 2014 Feb;232(3)300-7.

articles.title: Recurrent MYOD1 mutations in pediatric and adult sclerosing and spindle cell rhabdomyosarcomas: evidence for a common pathogenesis.
articles.reference: Agaram NP et al. Genes, chromosomes & cancer. 2014 Sep;53(9)779-87.

articles.title: MyoD and the transcriptional control of myogenesis.
articles.reference: Berkes CA et al. Seminars in cell & developmental biology. 2005 Aug-Oct;16(4-5)585-95.

articles.title: [Discovery of a new mutation in MYOD1 characterizes a subset of aggressive embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma partnering with mutations of the PI3K-AKT pathway].

articles.title: A recurrent neomorphic mutation in MYOD1 defines a clinically aggressive subset of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma associated with PI3K-AKT pathway mutations.
articles.reference: Kohsaka S et al. Nature genetics. 2014 Jun;46(6)595-600.

desc: MYOD1 encodes a transcription factor involved in muscle cell differentiation.
